subsubsection.title: Special Trig Limits
subsubsection.p: There are two limits of trigonometric functions that we will take advantage of in Section 2.4.

statement.p: The proof refers to the following picture:

image.description: This is a circle of radius 1 with a line drawn from the origin to the point A = (1,0), another drawn from the origin to D=(1,1) passing through the point on the circle B. A line segment is drawn from D to A, and another is drawn from B to some point E on the line segment AD. A final line segment is drawn from B to the line OA, whose intersection is point C.

statement.p:
First note that since we are on a unit circle, \sin\theta = |BC| which must be smaller than |AB|. In turn, |AB| \lt \text{Arc } AB = \theta. Rearranging, we see that
\sin\theta \lt \theta \iff \dfrac{\sin\theta}{\theta} \lt 1

If \theta \lt \tan \theta, then \theta \lt \dfrac{\sin\theta}{\cos\theta}\iff \cos\theta \lt \dfrac{\sin\theta}{\theta}. Combining with our first result, we have that
\cos\theta \lt \dfrac{\sin\theta}{\theta} \lt 1

Now apply the Squeeze Theorem. \ds \lim_{\theta\to 0} \cos\theta = \lim_{\theta\to 0} 1 = 1, so the Squeeze Theorem gives that
\ds \lim_{\theta\to 0} \dfrac{\sin\theta}{\theta} = 1

example.statement: Use the limits above to show that \dfrac{d}{dx}\left[\sin x\right] = \cos x.

solution.p: We'll use the definition of the derivative and the sum identity for sine: \sin(\alpha + \beta) = \sin\alpha\cos\beta + \sin\beta\cos\alpha.

example.statement: Find the derivative of f(x) = \cos x.

solution.p: We'll use the same approach as we did for sine, but will use the sum identity for cosine: \cos (\alpha + \beta) = \cos\alpha\cos\beta - \sin\alpha\sin\beta

example.statement: Differentiate y = u(a\cos u + b\cot u), where a,b are constants.

solution.m: y' = a\cos u + b\cot u + u(-a\sin u - b\csc^2u)
y' = 2x\sin x\tan x + x^2\cos x\tan x + x^2\sin x\sec^2x

example.statement: Find the derivative of y = \dfrac{t\sin t}{1+t}

solution.m: y' = \dfrac{(\sin t + t\cos t)(1+t) - t\sin t}{(1+t)^2}
